data.text: Contents
Local Arrangements to identify all eligible babies and procedure ......................... 6
Purpose
To outline the local guidelines of the Newborn Hearing Screening Service as agreed through the National Screening Programme.
To highlight the points where local practises deviate from the national hearing protocol.
To ensure all staff using the facility understand the philosophy of the service and work as a team providing family friendly care to the newborn babies and their parents.
Equality impact assessment
Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to Appendix 4)
Background

At least one in every 842 babies born in the UK will have a permanent childhood hearing impairment that can significantly affect their language and social development. This figure increases to about 3 in every 1000 babies who have spent more than  hours in intensive care. The majority of these babies are born into families with no experience or history of hearing loss.

The NHS Newborn Hearing Screening Programme (NHSP) was commissioned by Public Health following a report in 1997 which showed that the previous way in which early hearing impairment was detected, the health visitor distraction test carried out at around 8 months of age, missed a large number of children and that almost a quarter of children born deaf in the UK were not identified until they were three and a half or older.
Roles and responsibilities

The Specialist Nurse for Guidelines and Audit is responsible for ensuring clinical policies, guidelines and SOPs, are evidence-based and developed in line with national guidelines and following appropriate consultation.
The clinical director is responsible for the implementation of this guideline within the directorate.
The Head of Midwifery, maternity and Neonatal matrons and managers are responsible for ensuring maternity staff are aware of the guideline and implement it.
All staff are responsible for ensuring they are familiar with this guideline in relation to their practice and have the appropriate skills to implement this guideline.
Team Leader
4.5.1  Team Leader is responsible for the management, quality assurance and clinical governance of all aspects of the local screening programme.
Local Screening Manager

4.6.1 The Local Screening Manager is the operational lead for the NHS Newborn Hearing Screening Programme and is responsible for the day to day management of all aspects of the programme, audit and quality assurance of the newborn hearing screening service. When the local Screening Manager is away the hearing screeners cover the day to day service and report any issues to the Team Leader or the Maternity Manager.
Hearing Screeners

4.7.1  Screeners role is to carry out the hearing screen of newborns within the Maternity Unit and Outpatient Clinics and accurately record clinical and test data on S4H and record attendance and disposal on Lorenzo. (Refer to Appendix 3)
Aims of screening
The aim of Newborn Hearing Screening is the early identification of all children who have a significant permanent childhood hearing impairment (PCHI) in the neonatal period.

There are two screens that are undertaken by the Newborn Hearing Screeners, the OAE (Oto Acoustic Emission). This is done by sending a gentle sound down the ear canal. When this reaches the cochlea (part of the inner ear), this will send back an echo, which is recorded by a microphone that is in the ear tip. Once this reaches the parameters set by the Audiologist, the screen will stop and a CR (Clear Response) will appear. Sometimes there are reasons that we do not get a clear response, which could be one of the following reasons, 1) Birth fluid in the ear canal; 2) Unsettled baby; 3) Noisy ward. If this happens a no clear response will be recorded and an outpatient appointment will usually be given for the parents to bring the baby to an outreach clinic at a later date for a rescreen

The ABR (Automated Brain Stem Response) screen is where sensors are placed on the forehead, nape of the neck and shoulder, a gentle sound is then played through the headphones and as the sound reaches the auditory nerve an electrical impulse is given off from the nape of the neck and the forehead which is recorded. A sensor is also placed on the shoulder as muscle movement is also an electrical impulse and this differentiates between the response required and the muscle movement.
Scope of the service
The Newborn Hearing Screen is offered to all newborn babies born within Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust.

Babies should be screened at birth from around 6 hours old and within the first twelve weeks of life. In view of the high turnover locally we are screening early after 2 hours with a provision of repeating if necessary in local clinic. After  weeks screening is difficult to complete due to changes in the middle ear anatomy and also the baby becoming more alert to the surroundings.

To meet National Quality Standards, screening should be completed within the first 4 weeks. The gestation of the baby has to be  weeks and well for the screen to take place. This is due to the middle ear being developed enough to obtain a response. If a baby does not get clear responses following the ABR screen the baby is referred to the Audiology Department for a diagnostic test.
Local arrangements to identify all eligible babies and procedure

On a daily basis the Newborn Hearing Screening Database Smart4hearing (S4H) is checked for new births. Once the birth notification is completed by the midwife a NHS number is generated for the baby, the baby's details are fed through to S4H.
In the event of the S4H not working the hearing screeners are advised to print Lorenzo ward lists and print off the babies that need screening. The delivery registers are also checked.
The ward list is then checked against the patient bed board, these are located on the Co- located Birthing Unit and Labour Ward

On the Postnatal Ward a list is written up for the hearing screeners by the night staff informing of patients, method of delivery and whether there are any alerts i.e. Safeguarding or on the Neonatal Unit (NNU).

The Accuscreen (the machine to record the readings) machines are calibrated daily to check that everything is working properly. A probe test is carried out to make sure that the probe is working properly and is not blocked (the probe being the part of the equipment that is placed in the baby's ear). A cavity test is also carried out whereby the probe is placed in a cavity box (a small sealed empty container), and the screen is started, this should result in a referral for this to be working properly. Performing a test screen by placing an ear tip into an adult ear and recording the result checks the working of the probe. Checking the ABR (Automated Brain Stem Response) checks that the leads are connected correctly and the sound is audible.

The  parents  are  then  approached  and  offered  the  screen;  verbal  consent is  obtained outlining that they are giving consent for the screen to be done and for the results to be held on a national database.

Babies who are on intravenous (IV) antibiotics are screened but their levels are looked up once discharge has taken place and if their results are above the therapeutic level of 2mg/litre, then a targeted follow up appointment will be arranged within the community when the baby is 7-9 months old to check there has not been a deterioration in hearing due to antibiotics.

Targeted follow up appointments are referred to the Community Audiologist. Once a month these are printed off, checked by the hearing screeners that the targeted follow up is required. A referral is sent to Community Paediatric Audiology and the data is added to S4H by the Audiologist.
The details of the baby (usually the NHS number and surname and date of
birth) are input into the Accuscreen, the wires are cleaned with an alcohol wipe and a new ear tip (ear tips are disposable rubber tips in different sized) placed on to the probe.
The correct sized ear tip is then chosen and placed on to the probe which is then placed into a settled baby's ear canal and the screen is started.
The hearing screen usually takes only a few seconds and each ear is screened separately, the tip being changed or cleaned if necessary and the probe cleaned.

If clear responses are obtained in both ears the screen is then complete. The results are written into the Child Red Health Record Book and a copy of the results is removed for the hospital records. The screener will explain to parent that a copy of the hearing screen record is to be removed by the Health Visitor to document in Child Health and GP record. In addition parents are informed that there are two check lists in the Health Record Book for further guidance with regards to the baby's reaction to sounds and making sounds over the next 36 months. The result sheet is filed in the baby's postnatal booklet.

If a referral is obtained in either one of both ears, the baby will be offered an outpatient appointment to have a further screen. The appointment is given to parents before leaving the Maternity Unit. Appointments are booked by the screeners on the Lorenzo system. Babies discharged outside screening hours are telephoned the following day and offered outpatient appointment within national target (4 weeks) and letter sent confirming date, time and location of appointment.

The results are written into the newborn's Child Red Health Record Book and will be updated in the outpatient clinic once the hearing screen is complete. This is also documented in the baby's postnatal booklet.

Babies who are born at home are offered an outpatient appointment once a proforma is printed off S4H with the babies' birth details. This is generated by Child Health Department once the community midwife has informed them of birth.
Babies that are in need of special or intensive care, and are in the Neonatal Unit for more than  hours, will automatically require both screens, OAE and ABR.

The baby needs to be 34 weeks gestation before being offered the screen, be fit and well, ready for discharge and an Audiology Surveillance form needs to have been completed by a senior nurse/doctor on the Neo Natal Unit and given to the hearing screener before the screen can take place.

The audiology surveillance form informs the hearing screener of any risk factors that may result in a further follow up appointment in the community at 7-9 months or if a baby requires a direct referral to Audiology

Should the baby return to the postnatal ward before being discharged home, and have been on the neo natal unit for more than  hours, the Senior House Officer on the Postnatal Ward must fill in the Audiology Surveillance form before the screen can take place.

If the baby required a referral to Audiology, the appointment letter is given to the parent together with a leaflet “Your Baby's Visit to the Audiology Department”. The appointment is booked by the hearing screeners on the Lorenzo system. This appointment must be within four weeks of the first screen taking place, to meet National Quality Standards.
If the parent is not present at the time of the screen the Hearing Screener will telephone the parent with the result of the screen and will document this on S4H.

Once the baby has been seen in the Audiology Department, the results are added to the database by the Audiologist within timescale. The Audiology department telephones parents/guardian prior to appointment to confirm attendance. In the event of baby not attending appointment a further appointment will be offered. Audiology call the parents on the day of DNA and add appointment to S4H, Auditbase and Lorenzo. Health Visitor, GP and Safeguarding team are informed if baby does not attend this appointment or there are any concerns.

Babies requiring a targeted follow up due to risk factors identified, the referral is sent by the hearing screener to Community Paediatric Audiology at the end of each month for an appointment to be arranged in the community when 7-9 months of age.

Data is uploaded electronically from screening equipment directly onto the database by the hearing screener each day. If S4H is not working this will be completed as soon as S4H problems are rectified.
If a protocol needs to be overridden the hearing screener will add a case note with the reason and inform the manager.
Newborn Hearing Screening – Patient Journey will be reviewed every two years and prior if service changes occur. (Refer to Appendix 1)

Deceased babies are informed by Child Health Department to the NHSP Manager and copied to Senior Newborn Hearing Screener as soon as they receive notification. The record is marked as deceased on S4H and Lorenzo.
Training requirements

All Newborn Hearing Screeners must undertake the Diploma for Health Screeners qualification and sit the external competency assessment (ECA). Modules and in house training are supported by the Local Screening Manager.
Newborn Hearing Screeners must attend mandatory training and ‘safeguarding children and young people level 3' in accordance with the Trust training needs analysis.
Practical assessments are completed by the Local Screening Manager yearly prior to appraisal.
Newborn Hearing Screeners complete e-learning units for refresher of competency yearly.
Guideline Management

8.5.1 As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.
8.5.2 Local Screening Manager meets regularly with Team Leader to check current guidelines to maintain quality standards in line with NHSP Guidelines for Surveillance.
Infection prevention
The Hearing Screening Service will be delivered in accordance with and in compliance to the Trust's Infection Prevention Policies. (Refer to Trust Infection Prevention Policy; register number 04071)
Hearing screeners wear full PPE on wards and in outpatient clinic's changing between each baby.
Hearing screening equipment must be cleaned daily and recorded on the calibration record sheet held for each piece of equipment.
Ear tips, ear muffins and sensors are for single use only. NHSP manager monitors stock levels and places orders when required.
Hearing screening staff will be monitored for compliance. The service is supported by Infection Prevention Team.
Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved locally by the Maternity and Gynaecology or Paediatric Practice Steering Group prior to submission to the Controlled Document team for ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the Guidelines and Audit Nurse's and author's responsibility to inform the appropriate staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Auditing and monitoring

Team Leader, Head of Midwifery and NHSP Manager to review service yearly. To implement NHSP guidelines and audit before the end of year Children's Hearing Services Working Group (CHSWG) meeting where results will be presented. Minutes from CHSWG meetings are sent to Ante-natal & Newborn Screening Co-Ordinator for governance structure. Quarterly KPI data is presented at CHSWG and Ante-natal & Newborn Screening meetings by NHSP Manager.

The Team Leader and local Screening Manager will be accountable to the Public Health England Screening and Immunisation lead for delivery against the service specification. Attending (or ensure appropriate involvement in) local or regional meetings insofar as they relate to issues surrounding newborn hearing screening and paediatric audiology services, in order to keep up-to-date with national/local policy and likely future requirements for service development.
References

Newborn Hearing Screening Programme, 2012. Guidelines for surveillance and audiological referral of infants and children following the newborn hearing screen. London:Newborn Hearing Screening Programme. Available at: www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/494611/NHSP_Surv eillance_guidelines_v5-1_290612.pdf
Public Health England,  NHS Newborn hearing screening programme standards 2016 to  London:PHE. Available at: www.gov.uk/government/publications/newborn-hearing- screening-programme-quality-standards
Public Health England,  Newborn hearing screening care pathways. London:PHE. Available at:www.gov.uk/government/publications/newborn-hearing-screening-care- pathways
National Institute for Health and Care Excellence, 2006. Postnatal care up to 8 weeks after birth (CG37) London:NICE. Available at:www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg37

Newborn Hearing Screening Programme, 2013. Guidelines for the early audiological assessment and management of babies referred from the Newborn Hearing Screening Programme. London:BSA. Available at: www.thebsa.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/NHSP_NeonateAssess_2014.pdf
National Deaf Children's Society (NDCS), 2016. Newborn hearing screening. London:NDCS. Available at: www.ndcs.org.uk/information-and-support/first- diagnosis/newborn-hearing-screening//
